text: I would be willing to work on this as a student and submit a proposal.

text: Hi Kanishk - sorry I saw you already asked a month ago on github. So its at the moment not clear if and who from JuliaGraphs will participate but I try to figure out.

text: The way it worked in the past was, that student did not have an assigned mentor before the project was approved, but more that they submitted a proposal (with some help from the people here on slack)  and only afterwards got someone assigned

elements.text: The way it worked in the past was, that student did not have an assigned mentor before the project was approved, but more that they submitted a proposal (with some help from the people here on slack)  and only afterwards got someone assigned

text: I also have to warn you here: we only get a certain amount of slots from google that we do not now before - in the past there where always more good proposal than slots that we got

text: Speaking about DAG's do you think there is enough work there for 175 hours? (that is the target time you should spend on it according to google)

elements.text: Speaking about DAG's do you think there is enough work there for 175 hours? (that is the target time you should spend on it according to google)

text:
Hi Simon.

I understand that the slots are limited, but still I would be more than happy to prepare and submit a project proposal. 

 As for DAGs, my rough plan was to implement the DAG `type` and then the various algorithms that are specific to DAGs. For reference, NetworkX has 14 methods (a few of them are trivial though) in its DAG package. (<https://networkx.org/documentation/stable//reference/algorithms/dag.html|https://networkx.org/documentation/stable//reference/algorithms/dag.html>)

How all this maps to 175 hours exactly, I haven't honestly sketched it out yet. I was planning on looking at some of the older GSoC projects at Julia and then try to compare the workload, keeping in mind the coding period has been reduced to half this year. 
Also curious to hear what you think.
